title: MLB DFS Plays: Sunday 9/8
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We’ll take a comprehensive look across the DFS industry to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

Scroll to continue with content Ad

We will be looking at the 11-game main afternoon slate starting at 1:05 ET.

PITCHER

Jack Flaherty - St. Louis (at Pittsburgh)

This is a difficult decision, as Flaherty is priced similarly to de-facto aces like Max Scherzer, Noah Syndergaard, and Mike Clevinger. However, I believe the St. Louis righty has the best combination of matchup, salary, and current form of that group. Flaherty has been dealing lately, allowing just three earned runs over his past seven starts (46 IP). He’ll face a subpar Pittsburgh offense in pitcher-friendly PNC Park, which feeds the DFS rationale even more.

Also Consider: Max Scherzer, Noah Syndergaard

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Danny Santana - Texas (at Baltimore)

Story continues

The first base position is competitive this afternoon, but Santana jumps off the screen as a welcoming mid-range selection. It seems that any hitter with a pulse is in fantasy consideration against this terrible Orioles’ pitching staff, but Santana has proven upside while enjoying a career season with 24 homers supported by a respectable .286 average. The Rangers’ switch-hitter will look to exploit the .389 wOBA split (to LHB) of Baltimore RHP Asher Wojciechowski, and the Orioles’ bullpen should put up much resistance either.

Also Consider: Jose Abreu, Joey Votto

SECOND BASE

Robinson Cano - NY Mets (vs. Philadelphia)

Good ol’ Robbie Cano is back at it again, posting 13 hits with two homers and four doubles over his last six starts. He’ll take that heater into a favorable draw against Philadelphia RHP Vince Velasquez, who has surrendered 13 earned runs across 15.2 innings over his most recent four appearances. On top of that, the Phillies hurler owns a vulnerable .364 wOBA split to left-handed bats. Cano, Jeff McNeil, Michael Conforto, and other NYM lefties are firmly in consideration as a result.

Also Consider: Jose Altuve, Rougned Odor

THIRD BASE

Eduardo Escobar - Arizona (at Cincinnati)

Third base is usually an embarrassment of riches for any daily fantasy slate of 10 or more games. However, I had trouble finding legitimate options in favorable spots for reasonable salaries this afternoon. Escobar is one of the few lifts who checked those boxes, as he’ll face Reds’ RHP Anthony DeSclafani (.369 wOBA vs. LHB) in hitter-friendly Great American Ballpark.

Also consider: Yoan Moncada, Abraham Toro

SHORTSTOP

Tim Anderson - Chicago White Sox (vs. LA Angels)

I’m trying to make Alex Bregman fit into my lineup, but that doesn’t seem likely without sacrificing other positions. Anderson checks in as a comfortable fallback play, and I really like his contact/speed/power upside. The non-imposing salary doesn’t hurt either. Anderson will step in against LA Angels’ RHP Jaime Barria, who currently holds an inflated .369 wOBA split to right-handed bats.

Also Consider: Alex Bregman, Paul DeJong

OUTFIELD

Shohei Ohtani - LA Angels (vs. Chicago White Sox)

Ohtani came through in the first two games of this series, racking up five hits with two doubles, one triple, one homer, and five RBIs. He’s in a “smash spot” yet again while facing White Sox RHP Dylan Cease, who carries a .392 wOBA split to left-handed bats. Making matters even better, Ohtani’s salary remains low following a prolonged cold streak before this weekend series at Chicago. He’s certainly snapped out of that, and I’m expecting Ohtani to keep things going in this Sunday afternoon draw.

Josh Reddick - Houston (vs. Seattle)

Reddick doesn’t have promising career numbers against Seattle RHP Felix Hernandez, but we can all agree that this isn’t the same Cy Young caliber pitcher of previous seasons. In fact, the Astros represent the highest run-scoring projection of the main slate while facing Hernandez at home. Reddick is a cheap lift within that despite heating up to the tune of five hits and two homers over his last three starts.

Also consider: Yordan Alvarez, Michael Brantley, Tommy Pham, Willie Calhoun, Michael Conforto, Shin-Soo Choo, Jeff McNeil, Kole Calhoun
